description:
But before we do, meet the water man of Rajasthan. 30 years ago, Rajendra Singh gave up his government job in Jaipur and moved to a village without water. The rivers had dried up and most people had moved away. So he made it his mission to get the water back. And he's done it, not by some fancy modern method, but by reviving a tradition that had fallen out of use. He's just been awarded the respected Stockholm Water Prize. Rajendra told me through a translator how he ended up leaving the city for village life.

From the very beginning, I love to accept challenges. So I decided to leave city life, comforts of city life and decided to move to the villages. There was only one bus which would go from Jaipur to this area. When I boarded the bus, I didn't know where to go. So I asked the conductor, "Okay, you suggest where I should go." So the conductor gave me a ticket to a village called Kishori. It used to take four and a half hours.

When we reached Kishori village, I got off the bus. And let me remind you that was the time when there was a militant movement going on in the Punjab area. And the local villagers mistook me for a terrorist because I had a black beard, long black beard. They surrounded me and they started asking questions. And then somebody, one of the wiser men told the crowd that, "Why would a terrorist come to this village? There's nothing, there's no water, there's nothing to eat. Why would a terrorist come here? Give him a shelter."
